resources.string: Raw in salad, cooked or fried
No Kedusha as comes from outside Israel
Yes, in a tea or to give flavour to food
Yes (can be made into potato flour)
Yes - but should not be strained
May be dried – stem has no kedusha
May be peeled finely for a child or elderly person - may be dried
For adults can be mashed slightly.
If made into borscht – it retains kedusha
May be used to give flavour when pickling even if no intention to eat it. Should not be swallowed raw
Squeeze as much as possible and juice has kedusha
May be peeled finely or mashed for a child or elderly person. May be dried for raisins.
May put lemon rind (peel) into dough for flavour. Cannot be used for removing stains.
Can remove \'bad\' parts of it even if some good parts will come with it.
Careful when throwing away the seeds not to waste any fruit
Biur for olives/oil is Shevuos of 8th year
May be minced for fish - juice has kedusha. Can be cooked with chicken even if onions will not be eaten
Squeeze as much as possible and juice is kedusha
May be peeled finely or mashed for a child or elderly person
Making peanut oil from shmittah peanuts is subject to a dispute
May be peeled for a child
The Water it is cooked in has no Kedusha
May be cut even if some juice will be lost.
How may it be prepared or eaten:

Thought that this might make Shmittah easier for you
Check out The Shmittah App for Android (iPhone coming soon!). I can\'t believe how much it\'s already helped me. Just go to TheShmittahApp.com.
Brief Overview of the Halachos - Ebook
removel of shmittah produce from ones house by the date it is no longer available in the field
The stage when flowers bud on fruit trees
A collective sale of land in Eretz yisarael to non-Jews that allows agriculture to continue as usual
Produce that was grown in Israel during the shmittah year on land owned by Jewish people
Storehouses belonging to a Beis Din that acts on behalf of the public to provide produce

When Chazal saw that people were transgressing the laws of shmittah \ and planting in their fields during the shmittah year while claiming that the produce grew \ by itself, they forbade eating anything that grew, even by itself. Items which grew by themselves \ are termed sefichim and, in accord with Chazal’s directive, are prohibited. The logic behind \ the decree is that there is no incentive to plant the seeds during Shmittah if the produce \ cannot, in any event, be eaten.
The seventh year of the agricultural cycle in Eretz Yisrael
A specific bin that produce with kedusha must be kept in until it spoils
The Shmittah App was developed by Yitz Lefkowitz. Contact him for any and all Android app development. The app is currently in beta release, please look out for updates.
The material in The Shmittah App was taken with permission from The Pocket Halacha Series Written by Rabbi A. Wiesenfeld a Rosh Kollel and Maggid Shiur in Yerushalayim
To get started just tap the top-left corner of the screen, or else swipe from left to right.
The Shmittah App was developed by Yitzhak Lefkowitz in order to help people with their Shmittah observance. The app is currently in beta release, please look out for updates.

The information in The Shmittah App was taken with permission from The Pocket Halacha Series - \"Shmittah in the Kitchen\" a popular addition to the growing Pocket Halachos Series written by Rabbi Avraham Wiesenfeld.

Rabbi Avraham Wiesenfeld is the Rosh Kollel of a Halacha Kollel in Romema, Yerushalayim, a Maggid Shiur in various yeshivos in Yerushalayim and a sought after speaker, both in Israel and in the UK. He is the author of the popular book \"Kashrus in the Kitchen - QA\" published by Feldheim which has sold thousands of copies worldwide.
The information on fruits and vegetables was sent as a chart form to over 50,000 people in Israel.
If you want to organize a shiur on the Halachos of Shmittah or any other topic from Rabbi Wiesenfeld - please send a message though the \"Ask the Rabbi\" menu option.
Thank you Kayla Jacobs from New York who gave me the idea for this project
Is there a mitzvah to eat shmittah produce?
When buying canned fruit or vegetables, is there a way to determine if the product is from the seventh year?
Does one have to be careful of shmittah produce when one is outside of Eretz Yisrael?
Is it important to buy produce with a good hechsher during shmittah?
May one give fruits of sheviis to a child?
May fruits that have kedushas sheviis be eaten raw?
Is it permitted to add orange juice or grape juice that has kedushas sheviis into a cake or meat for flavour?
After using a utensil for squeezing/grating the fruit/vegetable with kedushas sheviis, may it be washed (causing the leftover food to be discarded immediately)?
If one may not ruin foods with kedushas sheviis, what can be done with leftover food?
May spices that were used for cooking and are now spent of their taste be thrown out normally?
May one feed shmittah fruit/vegetables to animals?
What can be done with animal food that is shmittah produce?
May one use a lemon with kedushas sheviis to remove stains from clothing?
If one has a non-Jewish worker who wishes to eat something, must one stop him from eating produce that has kedushas sheviis?
May dishes be washed normally if they have leftover shmittah food on them?
Is it permitted to make havdalah with kedushas sheviis wine/grape juice?
Is there a problem with buying a non-shmittah item from a Jewish owned store that also sells shmittah produce (and thereby does not keep the laws of shmittah)?
Does this same problem apply when buying from a non-Jewish owned shop, e.g., outside israel?
May a person who borrowed fruit/vegetables from a neighbour pay them back with kedushas sheviis produce?
Do flowers that grow during shmittah have kedushas sheviis?
May the flowers be thrown away normally?
May flowers/plants be bought from anyone?
May shmittah flowers be placed into water and cut before being placed into a vase?
May one grow an avocado in water during shmittah?
Can I level the ground to make the succah easier to sit in the succah?
If ones bush is blocking the path to ones house, may it be trimmed?
Can one move around his flowerpots as usual during shmittah?
Although some authorities claim there is, the final halachah is that it is not a mitzvah, but it is still a very nice thing to do.

Yes, by way of the product code. For example, a code appearing as 06 273 2 indicates that the product was processed on the 2nd shift, day 273, year 2006. Similarly, the code 07 027 1 indicates processing on the 1st shift, day 27, year 2007.

Yes. Shmittah produce from Eretz Yisrael retains its kedushah even when exported. Therefore, up to thirty percent of the flowers sold in the United States are imported from Israel, and if they have a scent and were grown during shmittah, they may be forbidden, depending upon where they came from within Israel. And, Israeli fruit is sold commonly throughout Europe, and plenty makes its way to America as well. One must therefore consult local kashrus authorities for details. One must be especially watchful for vegetables that were exported from Eretz Yisrael, which is very common, since they may be forbidden to eat because of sefichim and other problems.
Yes. During the shmittah year (and for some time after) there are a great many factors and halachos involved, so it is very important to look for a trustworthy hechsher.

Yes, even though some of the food may be wasted. They should not, however, be given to a very young child that will play with them and thereby waste them. Care should be taken to give the child only that which he will eat, not extra which is likely to be wasted. Children (from the age of understanding) should be taught not to ruin/destroy food with kedushas sheviis.

Yes, provided that they are normally eaten this way. Thus, any fruit that is normally eaten raw (oranges, avocado, lettuce) may only be eaten raw, and fruit that is normally cooked (potato, squash, etc.) may not be eaten raw. Normal is defined as what many people do, even if it is not done by the majority.

Yes, if it is normally done. Similarly, one may put spices – even if they can be eaten by themselves – into a mixture of other food for taste. The leftover cake that has this orange or grape juice in it may not be thrown away or wasted.

Any food that is still fit for human consumption [or even animal consumption] – even if no-one actually intends to eat it – or peels and pits that have some edible food clinging to them may not be destroyed. Consequently, they may not be thrown normally into a bin containing other food and refuse that would render them inedible. Rather, one should have in one’s kitchen a dedicated shmittah bin into which one may place all the leftover food and wait until the food begins to rot; at that point one may dispose of the leftovers normally, since at this stage it is no longer fit for human consumption and has lost its kedushah. Another reason to have a shmittah bin is that it is disrespectful toward food that has kedushah to be thrown into a receptacle for dirty or mouldy items. -1- The bag in the bin should be changed every day or every few days depending on the usage; or the new food should be placed into a bag before being put into the bin so that it will not be destroyed by leftovers which have earlier been placed there and have already grown mouldy. -2-In a situation where having a shmittah bin is difficult, one may simply place the food in a plastic bag, seal the top, and place it into the regular bin, allowing the food to rot by itself. -3- Food may be removed from the shmittah bin and discarded normally once it has spoiled to the point of being inedible.

Any food that is still fit for human consumption should not be fed to animals. Once it is no longer fit for people, it may be given to animals. If one wishes to take shmittah food to feed to the animals, one should do so only with food that is no longer fit for human consumption.
Animal food with kedushas sheviis must be given to animals and may not be discarded in the normal way.
No. One may even give shmittah produce to a non-Jewish worker working in one’s house as a snack, provided it is not part of his payment for the job

If the remnants are insignificant such that they would usually not be gathered and saved, the dishes may be washed normally without regard for the remnants. If, however, they are significant enough such that one might gather and save them, they should be treated with kedusha and placed in the shmittah bin before the dishes are washed.

Yes. However, one should place a plate under the cup to catch whatever spills and pour it back into the cup or it should be drunk. Also, the candle may not be extinguished in the wine, and wine may not be dabbed into one’s pockets and upon the eyes.

No. however, since the money one may receive as change from the till may be ‘shmittah’ money (i.e., it was used by someone to buy shmittah produce), it must only be used for food items and eaten as shmittah. If the majority of the store sells non shmittah produce, one need not be concerned every time he receives change from this store.
No, the money used to buy foods with kedushas sheviis from a non-Jew do not become shmittah money.

Some allow it if the food that was originally borrowed was also of shmittah. Nevertheless, the most preferable option when borrowing or repaying is to specify that the object being transferred is merely a gift. Thus, when one returns what one borrowed, it is not a debt being re-paid, but a present being given.

Flowers that are primarily valued for their beauty and emit no fragrance do not have kedushas sheviis. Some say that they even if such flowers do emit a fragrance, they do not have kedushas sheviis.In all cases, flowers may be smelled [except if they are sefichim according to some opinions].
Since the flowers one buys are mainly for beauty purposes, they do not have kedushah, and may be thrown away normally.

No. They may only be bought from a store that keeps the halachos of shmittah such that we can be assured they were not planted, tended to, or harvested in a forbidden way. If one did buy or received flowers from a questionable source, one may still use them normally. When buying a plant during shmittah from a store that keeps the laws of shmittah, some require that a plastic bag be placed all around the plant while transporting it home to prevent it from receiving nourishment from the ground (which would be like planting it).
They may be placed into a vase of water, even if this will cause the flower to open up
Yes – provided the boards are out showing clearly ones intention is only to make sitting in the succah easier and not to work the land in any way. Additionally, one should use non professional tools.
Yes, provided it is not done in a professional manner.

Absolutely not. There is a difference if the flowerpot is getting nourishment from the ground or not, and whether the place it will be moved to is a place where it can receive nourishment. This requires a lot of information.one should consult a rav before moving plants around – even in ones house.
Sorry, but we couldn\'t find anything matching

Thanks for using The Shmittah App. I\'ve put a lot of work into this \ project so I\'m asking users to help out a bit. The plan is to keep The Shmittah App free so \ that people have the halachos literally in their pockets.
Money goes towards updates as well as future Torah apps. Please keep in mind that there aren\'t\ that many Torah observant Jews living in Israel who own a smartphone.
To donate just click the button below. You can choose how much \ you want to donate after you click. Recommended donation is $5.
